headline: Private delivery firms eye bigger market share as strikes plague Canada Post
summary: (Reuters) -UPS, FedEx and other private parcel carriers are busy cornering a bigger share of the nearly $17 billion Canadian delivery market, while government-owned Canada Post copes with labor turmoil.  Canada Post, the country's primary postal service, has been plagued by labor disruptions since last year, including during the peak holiday season as workers went on strike over pay.  The Canadian Union of Postal Workers (CUPW), representing delivery personnel at Canada Post, initiated a nationwide overtime ban in May after contract negotiations failed.

headline: UPS Looks to Cut Costs to Mitigate Demand Woes: What's the Road Ahead?
summary: United Parcel Service trims 20,000 jobs, offers driver buyouts and shuts facilities to cut costs amid weak demand and rising labor expenses.

headline: The Top 5 Analyst Questions From FedEx’s Q2 Earnings Call
summary: FedEx’s second quarter results were met with a negative reaction from the market, as flat sales and persistent headwinds weighed on sentiment. Management pointed to ongoing challenges in global trade, including the expiration of the U.S. Postal Service contract and recent tariff changes, as key drivers of performance. CEO Raj Subramaniam noted, “Our higher margin B2B volumes remain pressured,” but highlighted the company's operational flexibility and cost-saving initiatives. Domestic parcel grow

headline: In its 30th anniversary, the BRAVO Business Awards will honor visionary leadership from Mercado Libre, Embraer, FedEx, and Corporación Multi Inversiones
